column1: Between 4 October 2019 and 1 April 2020, will legislation in a U.S. state allowing college athletes to receive financial compensation for their names, images, and/or likenesses become law?
column6: ['Business', 'US Policy']
Several state legislatures have already put these to Governors for signature. will be lost on the fog of current events but signals the end of amateur athletics. High schools next?

SB 646 (Intercollegiate Athlete Compensation and Rights) was sent to Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. He has 15 days to sign or veto the bill. Governor DeSantis has expressed support for the bill. I assume the governor will find time to make a decision on SB 646 during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Colorado signed but it does not become law until 2023. With the GJ question requiring “become law” I revert back to 0% chance.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/college/2020/03/20/colorado-governor-signs-college-athlete-name-image-likeness-bill/2887481001/
maintaining forecast. updating due to passage of time.
Decreasing probability based on states focusing on COVID-19 and the cancellation of most sporting events through the remainder of the survey period.
Passage of time. A lot if discussion but the country has other problems to solve.

I was not aware that there were multiple bills of this kind in the Florida House of Representatives and Senate (In my previous forecasts, I only mentioned HB 251). SB 646 passed the Florida House of Representatives and the Senate on March 13, 2020. It is now up to Governor DeSantis to sign the bill into law.

Most likely in Florida - with 2 weeks to go for governor to sign it into law. https://www.statesman.com/sports/20200314/florida-legislators-send-college-athlete-name-image-and-likeness-bill-to-governor
with the coronavirus-crisis not really
Dropping forecast because everything is slowing down due to COVID19. Although amendments and bills have been passed in a few states in the past week, the path to becoming law is a much longer shot
Drastically dropping this forecast. Due to Covid-19, there will be no rush to pass this law.
Covid-19. That will be the focus, and it's again unclear whether there's been any movement with (basically) two weeks to go.
The corona virus seems to be all consuming.
State legislatures will be distracted by corona virus beyond 1 April
Maybe California will rush through one positive change for good press in the midst of COVID stuff.
We've run out of time.

All the oxygen in the room is going to be sucked up by Covid-19, thus I can't imagine a situation in which a state takes time to pass this before the cut-off. For the athlete's sake let's hope we cynics are wrong #paytheplayers.

Downgrading to "just barely above no-way, no-how". All states are going to be overwhelmed with Coronavirus response. No state is going to have the time or inclination to handle this kind of legislation in March 2020.
Looking at the track the world.is on with people's rights, it makes common sense that this law will be passed
FL, CT, NJ and KS are all circling closer to passing legislation. Raising estimate, but still only 40 percent because the timing of when the states will pass legislation is still uncertain.
reducing forecast due to passage of time.

New update in NJ. The NJ bill has now cleared committee and now heads to the assembly speaker for consideration [1]. It is unclear how long that process will take, from the assembly speaker to law, but it seems unlikely to occur within a month. Correct me if I'm wildly wrong on that front.
From what I can tell there's been no movement towards making the thing happen since my last forecast (26/02), so I'm cutting down the probability by a few points.
Decreasing by 1%. I don't see any movement on this question.

While I initially thought this was likely to happen- it's the first week of march and I'm not finding any data anywhere on discussions of this happening in the next 3 weeks. It seems states are more concerned with primaries and taking measures to prevent the spread of corona. The NCAA has given them until January 2021 to create the rules.

The time I came to this question means there's barely a month, which means it'd probably be rushed if it did happen, and that would require a reason to rush which there isn't really. It seems like it's in the works in New Jersey or something, but I'm still not sure it's likely to get through.
Lowering as NJ bill continues to be stuck in committee
Decreasing by 1%. I still don't see the bill on upcoming NJ agendas.

Changing my forecast to account for a revised assumption about the meaning of this question. Since CA's bill was signed by the Gov before 4 Oct, this question regards every state BUT CA. And, I will assume that a bill "becomes law" when it's signed by the state's executive.

Based on the wide variety of estimates, I think there's some confusion about this question, particularly what it means for something to "become law". The CA law is already passed but won't take effect until 2023. Since this question is still open, I have to assume it will be resolved when a state's law actually "takes effect". Since even in CA that won't happen until 2023, there's no conceivable way any other state could pass a law and have it "take effect" in the next 40 days.
Maintaining current postion

Increased slightly based on New Jersey's recent movement on legislation. However, the NCAA appears to be accepting California's law and has developed a timeline for each NCAA division to review implications and develop legislative proposals (for the NCAA, not states) to be voted on during next year's NCAA Convention (January 2021). With the NCAA taking proactive actions to implement the change, other states may be less inclined to develop their own legislative requirements. http://www.ncaa.org/about/taking-action

Decreasing by 1%. This question is hinged on New Jersey. The bill passed the Senate and is now with the Assembly Higher Education Committee. I just checked the legislative calendar and don't see the bill on the agenda for any session over the next week. It seems that the bill will make it through the Assembly given bi-partisan support, but I'm not sure how long it will take. Additionally, I do not know how long it typically takes before the Governor will sign it.
Other states will have to do this unless they want their NCAA teams to begin losing out to California teams.

New Jersey introduced bill S971 in their legislature (specifically the Senate) on January 27, 2020. The bill passed the Senate on February 10, 2020. The bill was received by the Assembly on February 13, 2020 and was referred to the Assembly's Higher Education Committee on the same day. If your look at New Jersey's legislative calendar (which runs from February 19, 2020 to March 26, 2020), S971 is not listed. I don't know how the legislative process works in New Jersey, but I would be surprised if the bill passed before or by April 1, 2020.
Increasing estimate slightly due to progress in NJ. https://www.tapinto.net/towns/nutley/sections/government/articles/nj-state-senate-passes-new-jersey-fair-play-act-5

Great analysis by @DukeNuke, but to echo @RabbottAbbott11, it looks like New Jersey passed the bill through the Senate but still needs to get through the House and the Governor. The bill was introduced to the Senate on 27 Jan and passed on 10 Feb. I'm not sure though if that timeline is similar for the House and the Governor, but I'm skeptical. Of all the states with proposals, NJ seems to be the closest; however, I'm decreasing my forecast by 3% due to this question most likely hinging on one state pushing the bill through in roughly 6 weeks.

Increasing due to New Jersey's efforts. Senate Bill 971 was passed through the Senate on 2/10/2020 with a vote of 21-10 (8 not voting). It must now pass through the House, then be signed by the Governor. Still a lot of work to be done, but it is getting closer to becoming law in NJ.

Terrific research into each state's efforts by DukeNuke below. After reviewing the links for the various bills, I concur that the odds are extremely low that any state would be able to pass a law (this excludes the CA bill, which precedes this question's time frame) in the next 46 days. However, another contributor pointed out that there is a very strong incentive for other states to pass something this spring so CA doesn't end up with a significant recruiting advantage (even though their law won't take effect until 1 Jan 2023). It seems clear also that federal legislation will be required, but that will be many months, if not years, from now at best. So, the most likely scenario is that a state passes something simple (or maybe even symbolic) that meets the threshold of this question for the purpose of competing against CA.

New Jersey Fair Play Act passes General Assembly in December https://www.insidernj.com/press-release/new-jersey-fair-play-act-measures-banning-smoking-airport-pickup-areas-establishing-regional-health-hub-program-thursday-assembly-panel-agendas/
Somewhere, it will happen.

At the moment, the states of Colorado, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, Maryland, Minnesota, Nevada, New York, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Washington have all introduced or a considering legislation allowing college athletes to receive financial compensation for their name and/or image. So far, the states that have introduced legislation in their state houses and/or senate are Florida, Illinois, New York and Washington.

Issue is important. As written CA passed such as law before the Oct 2019 to April 1, 2020 period. CA is a big dog and I have to believe at least one of the other 49 states will follow their lead. Who want to risk the disadvantage in recruiting.
time's running out
The California law appears to be somewhat controversial, so other states will probably wait. http://www.ncaa.org/questions-and-answers-name-image-and-likeness
Time is running out...
Impeachment and election are distracting many lawmakers.

basing my forecast on likelihood of state legislatures meeting in time to consider and pass legislation. New York legislation seems to be most progressive and is still in committee at this time. Would have to pass floor debate, and senate and assembly before becoming law which appears to me to be unlikely at this point. Additionally, NCAA Federal and State legislative committee is still gathering information and working through a April 2020 deadline for a follow up recommendation but NCAA is against separate state bills and will push back against state efforts to legislate, in favor of a national law consistent across all states. Will monitor NY bill and update accordingly.
Only two months left...

The NCAA is crafting rules due in 2021. California has passed legislation but I think given the controversial nature of this states will wait and or negotiate with the NCAA before they pass anything. https://fortune.com/2019/10/30/ncaa-decision-college-athletes-pay/
Too early and not enough time, it is a matter of time that the hypocrisy of the issue becomes recognized, thus there would be no more hypocrites!

The California "Fair Pay to Play" Act was introduced on 4 February 2019 and not signed into law until 30 September 2019. Given the almost eight month processing time, it's unlikely that other states with proposed legislation will be able to process their bills any faster. The states most likely to pass the law within this timeframe would be Florida (introduced 30 September 2019; first reading occurred on 14 January 2020) and Illinois (introduced 30 September 2019; passed House vote on 30 October 2019; last action in Senate on 15 December 2019 to refer to Assignments). A key determinant for other states may be how the NCAA responds to California's legislation. The 2020 NCAA Convention is currently underway in Anaheim, CA where two statements have already been issued on the topic: http://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/statement-federal-and-state-legislation-working-group-co-chairs-name-image-and-likeness-efforts http://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/di-board-presidential-forum-discuss-name-image-and-likeness-issues Additionally, the 9th Circuit Court has already asked the NCAA and Athletes to provide comment on how this legislation affects an already underway anti-trust suit related to student-athlete compensation.

Given the precedent that CA set and the NCAA board of governors vote to allow it, it seems likely (>50%) that another state will pass legislation aside from CA. Unfortunately, I'm unable to set a clear base rate, other than assessing that when one state has set a precedent and the governing body has expressed support that the chances for success are more positive than negative. The question is whether it will happen by 1 Apr in the at least 10 states who have bills in progress. I intend to research the status in each state but am placing my initial forecast at 63% due to the number of states trying to pass the legislation. The lack of urgency to pass the bill as soon as possible gives me pause in starting with a higher initial forecast.
Tweaking forecast down a bit. I haven't seen any activity lately.

FL rep Kione McGee introduced the bill as HB 25 last week. Effective date of 7-1-2020 It seems to be referred to committee per the designation "HJ 25" - but I don't see which House committee has it. In any event - in spot-reviewing the life cycle of 2019 bills that were enacted into law - it looks like it takes 6 months from filing to signing on something that has no real opposition (ex: HB 87: Registering and Titling of Vehicles and Vessels) A lot of bills die in committee(s) I don't know the degree of opposition in FL - but it is of a matter that I would think requires reflection and debate----and thus time. So to get this done in under 90 days seems implausible.

California support the college student-athletes to receive compensation for the use of the student’s talents. Most of the other states don't support this legislation, and they accept the legislation a type of dictating upon them. As of September 2019, there is no attempt about this legislation. Therefore, it is not likely the college athletes to receive financial compensation for their talents to become law.
it is simply the way 'things' are going !!

There will be legislation that become effective. That is a certainty as California has already passed such legislation. The real issue is whether there will be action by the NCAA to change their rules that will bring their rule and the legislation into conformance. I do not believe that they will in 2020.
Adjusting down due to passage of time. The amount of time it will take to pass legislation relative to the end date of the question is becoming more and more difficult to overcome
Because money rules and more than the players will benefit.

I hope so. We are not jocks so I never considered the time, practice, diet and focus it takes to reach the college level. Then you blow out your knee and you lost your scholarship and your body is forever less. It shouldn't be just colleges making money off these kids, but there will be a lot of lobbying money to make sure they don't get a piece of the pie.
Already enacted in California others will follow

dramatic (almost embarrassing) size of NCAA and collegiate profits from basketball and football programs (TV and endorsements), will shock and then motivate public support for athlete compensation packages (which is easy to figure, a percent of NCAA profits go into a fund, when athlete leaves school she gets a check).
Too early.
College players are now pros playing for room and board.

When a college or a company uses you name or you as a selling point as the do advertising a game on TV. That person should receive a royalty. It is their talent that is placing the college in the bowl game. Making the student responsible for all the money received by the college.

It's challenging to find a clear analog to this situation, despite the fact that CA is known for passing trend-setting legislation that has been discussed but not addressed at the federal level. Perhaps medical and then recreational marijuana share some similarities, in as much as they were long discussed and debated before one state made a move that appeared to create a cascade effect. While recreational marijuana shares some of the competitive incentives that characterize "fair pay to play;" unfortunately, WA and CO adopted their measures through ballot initiatives, so the potential analogy breaks down.

Similar legislation is being discussed in at least 20 other states (https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/colleges/the-ncaa-is-still-whining-about-pay-to-play-its-too-late-for-that/2019/10/16/d128a2c8-f01e-11e9-8693-f487e46784aa_story.html), but these types of laws don't seem to become official very quickly. Thus, I think this is very likely to become the law in many states, but the timeline might be longer than the 1 April 2020 deadline of this question. It is also unclear that NCAA will change their rules that quickly, although they probably will before the CA legislation goes into effect in 2023).
Update for passage of time.
Maintaining current forecast

NCAA is supporting CA ruling, but it will take some time (years) to go into effect. There is little incentive for other states to add legislation prior to NCAA rule changes when it is clear it will do so.
Timing will be difficult despite new California legislation

NCAA working on rules after okaying this. States might hold up until those rules are out. http://www.pewtrusts.org/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2019/04/26/these-state-lawmakers-want-college-athletes-to-get-paid
Despite many bills being introduced, the 1 April deadline does not leave a lot of time for the legislative process to work.
crowd forecast, need to do more research.

A brand-new state (Oklahoma) has just had a bill introduced, and a new nationwide poll showing 66% support for this issue has just come out: https://www.courant.com/sports/college/hc-sp-ncaa-athletes-endorsements-poll-20200106-20200106-k4mkpovh6zfytetsqprmp5lxjq-story.html
State legislative processes simply take a long time, so 90 days seems too soon. Kudos to @Tuzlarob for some research that made me reconsider the speed of such an effort.
Updating based on written contributions from several forecasters.
inertia is a real bump in the road when dealing with state institutions cautiously trying to make sure they monetize it in a way most favorable to the Universities.

California's bill already became law in 2019, but did so outside of the window specified in the question. According to multiple sites, the NCAA's board of governors voted on 29 October to allow college athletes to be compensated for the use of the name, image, and likeness (NIL). Several states have bills drafted and at various stages of drafting or approval including: Florida, New York, Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Washington, Maryland, Connecticut, and South Carolina. I have outlined the status of a few known bills at the state level based on an article from CBS sports journalist Matt Norlander.
maintaining forecast

Half the state legislatures are working on it now. Just one example: https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/bills/2019/s6722 So, with 25 states in various phases of such a law, if there is a 2% chance that any given one gets the bill into law by April 1st, that means a 60% chance. (To do the math, take .98 to the 25th power and then subtract that from 1.) Add in Washington, DC, and that gets us to 62%.
maintaining current forecast
NCAA will have to react anyway. There ist no real need to build up more pressure. But some politicians might want to use the issue to get (re-) elected.
maintaining current forecast
https://www.ajc.com/blog/politics/paying-the-worker-bees-billion-year-college-athletic-machine/rACz4TWm8L2s3zCTHMoV0N/
Overdue.
maintaining current postion

With California leading the way there's going to be other states willing to try like Washington or Colorado. With legalizing fiscal expenditures there's increased opportunity for players and state collegiate growth - all donors to politicians. With increasing collegiate programs taking in millions from ticket, merchandise, and donations, there's substantial fiscal reason to push legislation through in areas where colleges are on the verge of breaking in to mainstream adoption. By enabling fiscal compensation future year athletes will have renewed reasons to compete and declare their University of choice. With all those reasons there's still lingering governmental timelines to consider which weigh on the likelihood.
maintaining forecast
I wish it was higher, but there will be resistance, and Legislation sometimes Needs Long time to do ist work.
Maintaining forecast
Could see Oregon and/or Washington state following California's lead on this.
maintaining for now.

there are a few states where this is already in the hopper...election coming up...state legislative sessions tend to be in the early calendar year...beating up on the NCAA is pretty much the easiest political points on the board right now--really...what other issue passes the California legislative process with near unanimous bipartisian support???
maintaining current forecast.

Interesting read on the “race to the bottom” California’s bill has created. Seems like New York is the most likely state to act next, followed by Florida and Illinois. The number of states considering bills has also doubled since my initial forecast in October.
Dropping down to 35% based on NCAA response that seems to be creating a pause in legislation
Dangit I should never have tried to forecast this one, I don't really understand what constitutes "become law" in the question. Hedging my bets...

Laws take forever to get presented, debated, examined, approved and enacted. Not much time between now and April 2020 for such a specific new law to come into force, even allowing for 50 different places where it might occur.
Based on the NCAA announcement (see link), I think laws will be accelerated with the organization not pushing back as hard.

Despite the NCAA announcement that it will allow college students to receive compensation for their image or likeness, states will continue to move forward with legislation to help push their agenda's into the conversation on what the new Pay to Play rules will look like. It appears all of the proposed bills have delayed implementation dates of 2021 and later which would allow negotiations with the NCAA. None of the legislators that have proposed bills are walking back their proposals. Rep. Emanuel Cleaver is even proposing federal regulations to drive the discussions and negotiations with the NCAA. I do not believe the NCAA's announcement will make any of the bills go away, I believe it will increase the urgency to pass them so that states can leverage their proposed laws in the negotiations with the NCAA.

https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/29/us/ncaa-athletes-compensation/index.html The NCAA is probably going to drag this out until your great-grandchildren are married, but for the purpose of this Q it won't matter: By next April, at least a few states will have passed laws allowing this, with effective dates delayed until the effective date of the NCAA's policy. That should resolve this one as a Yes, since effective dates don't matter.
The California Fair Pay to Play Act will not go into effect until Jan. 1, 2023.
Saw this news where this financial compensation could or might be taxed. Does this help accelerate the process? not sure within 6 month, but can't be discarded.
Following the reasoning provided by @dlaiocean. Keeping a few percentage points in yes just in case.
This is an update from my previous forecast [1].
A period of 6 months is too short for a change like this
The question is, will it be a law? Could it be NCAA is doing image control? Laws take long to be inforced.
NCAA ANNOUNCED NO OBJECTION TO REVENUE FROM USE OF IMAGES.

I’m not sure how the news today will affect the resolution of this question. On the one hand, the rules change from the NCAA will likely quell some concerns from state legislatures since the association is pursuing self-governance. On the other hand, there are still calls for action at the federal level.
NCAA just agreed on blanket compensation for image/likeness enabling States to use that. Individual State legislation likely unnecessary now.
The momentum is slow to pickup. NCAA wil fight this, so will take longer to resolve. When money is involved you need to know how much you are ready to lose.
Yes, considering that California seems to play a significant role on being a state where most laws begin to be updated and modernized.
It appears that several states are proposing similar legislation. Likely that 1 or more are approved as law.

FL likely to pass a law: https://www.ocala.com/news/20191024/florida-governor-supports-college-athlete-compensation/1 NJ submitted bill: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/2019/10/24/nj-college-athletes-pay-compensation-ncaa/4085461002/
Updating for passage of time and additional information
Self-glorification and aggrandizement, celebrity, influence, and money are America's main motivations - so we love sports.
Impeachment good time to pass bipartisan gimmes.

There is a clear movement in this direction driven by the athletes, but also supported by some politicians. I can see a clear outcome whereby the current situation is likened to unpaid labour or similar, and given the risk of injury etc for the athletes a move to compensate gains traction. For the colleges they can also attract sponsorship etc for better players and earn a cut.

It seems like a fairly popular idea. But, it is a large market controlled exclusively by NCAA. They have come out against any foray into compensation for players. Additionally, I think colleges will ultimately lobby against this legislation. It opens the door for employment claims.
This is ultimately about money. If college athletes can be compensated, then schools can attract better players. Also, schools can likely get a cut of that compensation.
California

Nine states have proposed legislation that is similar to California's. Illinois has a bill that has strong support that will be introduced in Oct and could be passed as early as Jan 1, 2020. Eight other states, several of them with full time legislatures have also proposed bills that could be signed into law soon, most notably New York. The bill has strong support there as well and has to potential to be passed spring of 2020. All bills, if signed into law, would take effect in 2023. With CA leading the way, other states are going to scramble quickly to ensure they can use this as a recruiting tool.

California passed unanimously (Democrats and Republicans) a law allowing student athletes to receive financial compensation for their names, images, and/or likenesses. The legislation is to take place in 2023. The long delay for the law to go into effect is due to the expected lawsuits from NCAA and other schools. Indeed, NCAA threatens to ban CA schools from participation in NCAA sports if the law goes into effect.
Up against some dodgy competition
11 States now proposing similar legislation. FL, IL, NY appear the most aggressive.
California is working on it
The NCAA will not accept creative destruction
CA already heading this way.
There was a uptick in California one can get paid for playing.
There is no reason for a state legislator to gake a stand on this. Better to wait for NCAAand CA to chew on the ramkfications. Kick the can down road, plenty of time.

A factor that I haven't seen in comments below is that basketball's final signing day is May 20th, 2020, football is April 1, 2020. When the law is passed is going to determine which recruiting cycle it affects. Football has a bunch of money, but basketball players could be more likely to get a big early endorsement. Especially with the one and done rule. Schools will also be considering if only a few states initially pass the law (even if it is after April) it will likely also have a significant impact on transfers. Next factor for me is can the legislation be passed that quickly (when that much money is involved, probably yes) mixed with how much they want it to factor into this recruiting cycle. Followed by what is the NCAA going to say in their meeting at the end of the month.
If I was a college athlete recruiter I'd want this legislation passed ASAP. What legislator wants to be seen as tying the hands of their state's college athletics program?

This is definitely something states are going to do in order to stay competitive with California schools. My hesitation is with the time frame, legislatures rarely move quickly so I think this will take more than six months.

Reducing since my math was incorrect on the probability of at least one of the five bills currently proposed being passed within the scope of this question. The correct probability is actually 40%. I still think there is a 45% chance the legislatures will act on a Bill given the NCAAs review later this month. As a result, my midpoint is now 42%
Average bill takes 215 days or roughly 7 months become law. As a results, that would require a base rate of <50%. https://www.quora.com/How-long-does-it-take-to-pass-a-bill-in-the-US/
NC, SC also in the mix.
why pay poor, underpriviliged kids when you can work them to the bone free of charge to line your own pockets

California is arguably more important to the NCAA and its constituent conferences than vice versa, so the latter will not likely follow through on the threat to disqualify California schools from the Official Competitions. The same, arguably, goes for Texas and Florida and several other states with very large collegiate sports audiences. Also, if compensation gives permitting states a recruiting advantage, which might reasonably be expected, other states are likely to fall in line as briskly as they can arrange to.

- It took CA 8 months from bill proposal to signature so April 1 would be very tight - Currently, 5 states proposing similar bills so just using straight math for now in my prediction - Many arguments for, many against - this is real disruption which makes it difficult to push forward but that much more desired by its proponents - Likely an NCAA lawsuit would be presented and States may prefer to have another pay to get a ruling vs. being the one that has to do it - NCAA completing a study this month to assess how it could operate with athlete compensation, something to watch out for and then assess further
https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/464268-california-inspires-other-states-to-push-to-pay-college-athletes

Sports Illustrated is tracking the variety of bills related to this question. [1] They suggest that about 9 states are considering laws on these issues. A few have been filed, but most are still in earlier stages of the legislative process. Politically, these bills do not seem to controversial (both Republicans and Democrats supported them in California). So, the main problem here is whether these bills can go through the legislative pipeline fast enough. In addition, it's unclear to me what incentives are for other states to pass these bills. On one hand the NCAA is not a powerful lobbyist at the state level, but I don't think there is great political gain in passing any of these bills. Similarly, I don't think there is any urgency for policy makers on these questions. I doubt any will get through in this 6 month period, but in a year or two I would assign a much higher probability. [1] https://www.si.com/college-football/2019/10/02/tracking-ncaa-fair-play-image-likeness-laws

Irrespective of the merits on this issue, the calendar is working against such a bill, which is certain to be controversial for reasons both good and the other thing. Between now and 1 April is not a time when most legislatures get anything complicated done. Many are already out of session, not to return until after the first of the year, and those that are still in are up against budget deadlines or are otherwise exhausted. The same, mutatis mutandis, will be true of those returning in January.
Its time for the NCAA to come clean and regents to just be upfront about it,
